Legal_Issue: Did the Commission err in not referring the applicant's complaint to the tribunal based on discrimination contrary to sections 7 and 10 of the Act?
Application_Facts: The applicant argued that Canada Post's hiring process discriminated against her Asperger Syndrome.
Decision_Outcome: The Commission dismissed the complaint, concluding that accommodations were offered and the evaluation standards were rationally connected to the job.
Remedy_Requested: Referral of the complaint to the tribunal
Court_Ruling: The judicial review was allowed, and the matter was referred back to the Commission for re-evaluation by a different investigator.
Defendant_Behavior: Canada Post's hiring process and accommodation practices
Legal_Standard: Sections 7 and 10 of the Canadian Human Rights Act prohibit discriminatory practices in employment
Assessment_Factor: Individualized assessment of disability in hiring process
Applicable_Legislation: Canadian Human Rights Act, sections 7, 10, 44(3)(b)(i); Federal Courts Act, subsection 18(1)
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review under subsection 18(1) of the Federal Courts Act
Legal_Provision_Cited: Sections 7 and 10 of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Application_Basis: Denial of employment opportunity due to disability without individualized assessment
Evidence_Assessed: Lack of individualized assessment of the applicant's disability
Relief_Sought: Overturning of Commission's dismissal and remand for re-evaluation
Governing_Rule: Sections 7 and 10 of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to conduct an individualized assessment of the applicant's disability
Harm_Assessment: Potential denial of employment opportunity due to disability-based discrimination
Cause_Description: Alleged discrimination during Canada Post's hiring process due to Asperger Syndrome

Legal_Provision_Violated: Sections 7 and 10 of the Canadian Human Rights Act
